Hello all!

My first Aielund completion has been done with a female paladin smiter, Cylla....I enjoyed the playthrough a lot, but wanted to try other classes and pcs....and then became WoG.

Bard fighters, sorcerer/Pal/CoTs, Bard sorcerers.....only arcane magic here, in WoG (offline). Then, the first PC in the server is a divine caster/meeler: next character for my playthroughs will be a PM STR fighter and, after that, a paladin smiter.
I have never found class splits as the below one; I understand that there is a "why", as it lacks the mega saves provided by Champion of Torm, and she has less strenght than Dragon lance by TyrTemplar (no RDD class).

However, I tried to balance smite power (up to great smite +5) with an average melee prowess. I post the draft, for your review.
I point out that, even if I though about playing the build in WoG, this is a general build. You can advise on which tweaks are more suited for this server.

Mundane damage is currently as 1d10+11 (17 with capped STR), but you can sum up:

+5 divine favor
+5 GMW

for a total of 51 damage (maximum rolls and capped abilities).

Base AB is 38 + 5 GMW + 5 divine favor + 1 prayer + 6 STR +1 aid = 56 AB.

Smite: usable up to 3 times per day, AB +8 (+14 with capped CHA) and damage 210 divine (420 if critical with a rapier/scimitar).

This class split is never reported in both the new and old ECB guild. Many are Paladins out there are Pally/Champion of Torm/Rogue or fighter.

The PC's focus is with an exotic weapon (bastard sword), to obtain more AC by going sword 'n board. The lesser strenght is partially compensated by weapon spec. / epic weap. spec..
However, a choice would be to revert to longsword/rapier or scimitar and  swap exotic prof feat for either expertise, craft wand (considering the low amount of spell slots, maybe this would be the better choice) or extend spell to double the slots for divine favor.

Anyone can clarify which is the minimum caster level to avoid Mords and why?
I have consulted the nwn wiki, but honestly I didn't understood 100% the rationale....

posts.author: Yunim
posts.content:
Overall it looks like a decent melee build with a nice trump card for any tough bosses. The Divine Might damage alone should be enough to finish off any enemies that your physical damage can't deal with.

My default smiter is a rapier-wielding Pal29/CoT10/Monk1 with Great Smiting X since there is a larger chance of a smite critical compared to other weapons. Although bastard sword does have higher base damage, I think that the increased threat range makes switching to rapier or scimitar worthwhile.

I think you should try to fit in Epic Prowess, either by dropping Armor Skin, dropping Great STR, or moving your pre-epic Fighter level to epic levels. I also think that Divine Shield is worth considering if you're planning on having a high AC, with fully buffed CHA you can potentially reach the dodge cap depending on the items available on your server.

Unless your server has altered Smite Evil then the extra damage is physical rather than divine, so it will be affected by DI/DR just as your regular physical attacks are.

There is no way to prevent vanilla Mords from dispelling your buffs, however since it is based on the dispeller's caster level your buffs can't be dispelled by a mage with 26 caster levels or less. The dispel check is Dispeller CL + 1d20 vs Buffer CL + 12, with a draw resulting in a dispel. In this case we have 26 + 20 = 46 vs 35 + 12 = 47, so a 26 CL dispeller can't win. This only affects the dispel effect of Mords though, the breach effect ignores caster level completely.

posts.content:
I don't know smiting builds very well but around base 400hp should be ok for a melee build particularly one so multiple attribute dependant

Kail Pendragon and Hip ran a thread somewhere in the forum on HP targets. If I find the thread I'll link it here, but roughly, there were some suggested HP targets for most environments that were agreed on:

300hp for support character (ie casters, rogues, archers clerics etc)
400hp for melee character
500hp for dedicated melee character

Maximillian Kane liked to drop the HP further than most so running a low HP build is not impossible (ie 200hp) but the comment was you might have troubles if you are the target of a few IGMSs

posts.author: Zanithar
posts.content:
Thanks for that, an interesting read.  I generally discount called shot on non-archer builds.  I’ll have to give it another whirl on a dualwield monk/fighter Kama chassis.

For full melee vs melee, I think it is safe to assume it is a level of dedicated investment.  I personally do not think it is as cut and dried as this as for me there is HP tanking, AC tanking, DR tanking.  Or, honestly, more commonly a combination of the above.

So, I suspect a definitive example of a full melee would be something like WM/Fi/Ro.  The entire build and skill focus is melee based.  Another example would be a deep barbarian build.

A “melee” build firmly on the hybrid side would be a Battle Cleric or a Spellsword style build or perhaps a deep Monk build.  If you can buff your HP (this includes equivalent HP through DR/DI) and/or heal yourself or mitigate damage in other ways then you can sit under the cap.  

My general rule is that my character needs to be able to survive a hasted delivery of IGMS on any server I am on as the minimum “buffed” HP equivalent.  A dedicated melee character needs to sit about + 50% equivalent HP above this.

So, on WoG, IGMS has been modified to max 15 missiles per target.  All my characters need to be able to survive a maximized double IGMS hit fully buffed.
15x2x2x6 (15 missiles x 2 spells 'hasted' x 2d6 'maximized') = 360 HP and my melee characters need to sit 50% above this = 540 HP.  This is my thumb in the air, fully equiped/buffed number.  So, for the build above with 438 HP, it would be a build priority for me to add another 100 HP in Con Equipment (+6 Con).  Which on a multi-stat build can be challenging, as a paladin has other ways to mitigate damage I might shave it down to +4 Con :)  Then I would adjust up and/or down a bit as I survive or do not survive encounters.  You also need to strongly consider death penalties, if you are on a server with significant penalties ... this all goes out the window.

Just as a counter point, on a server without an IGMS customization it would look like this:
20x2x2x6 = 480 HP and my melee characters need to sit 720 HP.  Again, this is fully buffed, so using the 300 / 400 / 500 spread in the link 500 HP + Con Cap (240 HP) = 740 HP, meaning my approach is not dissimilar in results but it is more flexible across various servers and customizations and most importantly ... it works well for me :)
